  "article_text": [
    "each group can be obtained by quotienting a free group by a normal subgroup generated by a set of relators . in @xcite gromov introduced the notion of a random finitely presented group on @xmath5 generators at density @xmath6 .",
    "the idea was to fix a set of @xmath7 generators and consider presentations with @xmath8 relators , each of which is a random reduced word of length @xmath9 .",
    "gromov investigated the properties of random groups when @xmath9 goes to infinity .",
    "we say that a property occurs in the gromov density model with _ overwhelming probability _ if the probability that a random group has this property converges to @xmath10 when @xmath11 .",
    "significant results of this theory are the following : for densities @xmath1 a random group is trivial with overwhelming probability ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 11 ) ; for densities @xmath12 a random group is , with overwhelming probability , infinite , hyperbolic and torsion - free ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 11 ) ; for densities @xmath13 a random group does not have property ( t ) with overwhelming probability ( * ? ? ?",
    "* corollary 7.5 ) .",
    "one modification of gromov s idea is the triangular model : length of relators in the presentation is always 3 , but we let the number of generators go to infinity .",
    "precisely , for a fixed density @xmath14 , we consider a presentation on @xmath0 generators with @xmath15 relations , each of which is a random reduced word of length @xmath16 .",
    "we say that some property occurs in the triangular model with _ overwhelming probability _ if the probability that a random group has this property converges to @xmath10 when @xmath17 .",
    "this model was introduced in @xcite and further studied in @xcite .",
    "the triangular model was a way to prove that random groups in the gromov density model for densities @xmath18 have property ( t ) with overwhelming probability ( * ? ? ? * theorem b ) , @xcite .",
    "we introduce a new random group model by considering a random set of relations , each of which is a random reduced word of length four .",
    "the following notation will be used in the whole paper    consider the set @xmath19 , which we will treat as an alphabet .",
    "let @xmath20 be the set of positive words of length 4 over @xmath21 and @xmath22 be the set of all cyclically reduced words of length 4 over @xmath21 .",
    "note that @xmath23 and @xmath24 up to a multiplicative constant .",
    "by @xmath25 we will denote the free group generated by the elements of @xmath21 . by _",
    "relators _ we will understand words over generators and by _ relations _ equalities holding in the group .",
    "[ def : gcar ] for @xmath6 let us choose randomly , with uniform distribution , a subset @xmath26 such that @xmath27 .",
    "quotienting @xmath25 by the normal closure of the set @xmath28 , we obtain a _",
    "random group in the positive square model at density d_.    [ def : overwhelming ] we say that property @xmath29 occurs in the positive square model with _ overwhelming probability _ if the probability that a random group has property @xmath29 converges to @xmath10 when @xmath17 .    the most important group properties which we consider are : being trivial , being free , being hyperbolic and having property ( t ) .",
    "we prove , as in the gromov model , that for densities @xmath30 a random group in the positive square model is trivial with overwhelming probability ( theorem [ thm : triv ] ) and that for densities @xmath2 a random group is with overwhelming probability hyperbolic ( corollary [ cor : hyp ] ) .",
    "moreover we show that for densities @xmath31 a random group in the positive square model does not have property ( t ) ( theorem [ thm : nt ] ) .",
    "inspired by the results in the triangular model we prove that for densities @xmath4 in the positive square model a random group is free with overwhelming probability ( theorem [ thm : free ] ) .",
    "we also introduce abstract diagrams with fixed edges ( definition [ def : fix ] ) and prove a generalization of the isoperimetric inequality ( theorem [ thm : lab ] ) .",
    "it is not known what is the optimal density threshold for a property of not having property ( t ) in the gromov density model .",
    "this model seems to be much harder to analyze than the triangular model , where we know that for densities @xmath32 a random group is free with overwhelming probability ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition 30 ) and that for densities @xmath18 a random group has property ( t ) with overwhelming probability ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem a ) , @xcite .    in our model",
    "we expect to find the critical density threshold for having property ( t ) in further research .",
    "we also expect that for densities @xmath32 a random group in the square model can be cubulated ( see @xcite for discussion about cubulating random groups in the gromov density model ) .",
    "the advantage of the positive square model is that since the length of relators is even , we can consider the hypergraphs in the presentation complex and cayley complex of the random group ( definition [ def : hyp ] ) , which is not possible in the triangular model . as we will see , hypergraphs are a useful tool to investigate many group theoretic and topological properties .",
    "we have decided to consider as relators only positive words to avoid technical annoyances , but we will show that all of our results remain true in a model where we allow non - positive words .",
    "firstly , we will define this model :    [ def : gcar ] for @xmath6 let us choose randomly , with uniform distribution , a subset @xmath33 such that @xmath34 .",
    "quotienting @xmath25 by the normal closure of the set @xmath28 , we obtain a _",
    "random group in the square model at density d_.    * acknowledgment*. i would like to thank piotr przytycki for suggesting the topic of this thesis , for his help , valuable suggestions and many interesting discussions .",
    "i am also grateful to irena danilczuk ",
    "jaworska , jerzy trzeciak and micha kotowski for improving this paper and many corrections .",
    "firstly we are going to investigate a case where there are many relations .",
    "inspired by the results in gromov s theory we have proved the theorem stating that when density is greater than  @xmath35 , random groups in positive square models are as trivial as possible ( with overwhelming probability ) .",
    "let us determine , , how trivial  can such a group be .",
    "the most obvious case is when all the generators are equal . in that case",
    "we indeed have only one generator , g , and , in the positive square model , only one relation @xmath36 ( by @xmath37 we denote the neutral element ) .",
    "it means that our group is isomorphic to @xmath38 .",
    "hence @xmath38 is the smallest group which can be obtained in the positive square models",
    ". we will call it",
    "_ trivial_.    our goal in this section is to prove the following theorem :    [ thm : triv ] in the positive square model at density @xmath39 a random group is trivial ( in the sense described above ) with overwhelming probability .",
    "before providing the proof we need to introduce random graphs and recall several facts about them .",
    "[ def : random_graph ] @xmath40 is the graph obtained by sampling uniformly from all graphs with @xmath0 vertices and @xmath7 edges .",
    "@xmath41 is the random graph obtained by starting with vertex set @xmath42 , letting @xmath43 , and connecting each pair of vertices by an edge with probability @xmath44 .    in general @xmath7 and @xmath44",
    "are functions of @xmath0 .",
    "we will say that a random graph in @xmath41 model has some property _ asymptotically almost surely _ if the probability that this property occurs converges to @xmath10 when @xmath17 .",
    "[ rem : graphs ] there is strong links between the two models .",
    "first note that the expected number of edges in @xmath41 model equals @xmath45 .",
    "if @xmath29 is any graph property which is monotone with respect to the subgraph ordering ( meaning that if @xmath46 is a subgraph of @xmath47 and @xmath46 satisfies @xmath29 , then @xmath47 satisfies @xmath29 as well ) , then the statements `` p holds in the erds and rnyi @xmath48 model with overwhelming probability '' and `` p holds in the gilbert @xmath49 model with overwhelming probability '' are equivalent if @xmath50 .",
    "graph properties which are monotone in the above sense and are relevant for us are : being connected and having a cycle of odd length .",
    "gilbert s model is much easier for calculations than erds ",
    "rnyi s one , so we will prove two lemmas in gilbert s model .",
    "[ lem : conn ] let @xmath51 be a random graph in @xmath41 model , where @xmath52 for some @xmath53 . then @xmath51 is connected asymptotically almost surely .    more general statements about connectedness of random graphs can be found for example in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 7.3 ) , but since we repeat the argument in the proof of lemma [ lem : cycle ] we present here a simple proof of lemma [ lem : conn ] .",
    "denote by @xmath54 the set of vertices of @xmath51 .",
    "note that disconnectedness means that there exist two nonempty sets @xmath55 such that @xmath56 , @xmath57 and there is no edge between @xmath58 and @xmath59 . for a fixed @xmath58 and @xmath59 the probability that there is no edge between @xmath58 and @xmath59 equals @xmath60 .",
    "hence the probability @xmath61 of disconnectedness can be estimated ( as of now we assume @xmath62 ) :    @xmath63    the right hand side can be estimated as follows    @xmath64    from our assumption on @xmath44 we know that    @xmath65    let us denote @xmath66 . because @xmath67 instead of proving that @xmath68 we can prove @xmath69 .",

    "hence , we estimate :    @xmath72    therefore , @xmath69 .",
    "thus the geometric series on the right hand side of ( [ eq : num ] ) converges to 0 when @xmath17 .",
    "[ lem : cycle ] let @xmath51 be a random graph in @xmath41 model , where @xmath52 for some @xmath53 .",
    "then asymptotically almost surely there is a cycle of odd length in @xmath51 .",
    "we will estimate the probability that our graph is connected and has no cycle of odd length .",
    "first we will prove that if the graph is connected and has no cycle of odd length then it is bipartite :    let @xmath54 be the set of vertices of @xmath51 .",
    "denote by @xmath59 the spanning tree of @xmath51 .",
    "such a tree exists from connectedness .",
    "fix some vertex @xmath73 .",
    "then we can define sets : @xmath74",

    "can be estimated :    @xmath81    the summation is over all sets @xmath46 and @xmath47 . in the last inequality we used the fact : @xmath82 . in the proof of lemma [ lem : conn ]",
    "we have already shown that the right hand side of ( [ cyc ] ) converges to 0 when @xmath17 .",
    "this ends the proof .",
    "[ rem : path ] let @xmath51 be a connected graph that has a cycle of odd length .",
    "let @xmath83 be vertices of @xmath51 .",
    "then there exists an edge path in @xmath51 of even length joining @xmath84 and @xmath85 .",
    "denote by @xmath86 the closed edge path in @xmath51 of odd length .",
    "let @xmath87 be the beginning vertex of @xmath86 .",
    "from connectedness of @xmath51 there exist edge paths @xmath88 from @xmath84 to @xmath87 and @xmath89 from @xmath87 to @xmath85 .",
    "if @xmath90 is an even number then @xmath91 is the desired edge path joining @xmath84 and @xmath85 .",
    "if @xmath90 is an odd number then @xmath92 is the desired edge path .",
    "now we are able to provide the proof of our main statement .",

    "[ lem : cycle ] we know that asymptotically almost surely graph @xmath113 is connected and has a cycle of odd length .",

    "[ rem : path ] asymptotically almost surely for any two vertices of @xmath51 there is a path of even length joining them .",
    "an edge between the vertices @xmath110 and @xmath111 of @xmath51 corresponds to the relation @xmath115 in our random group .",
    "an adjacent edge connecting @xmath111 and @xmath116 implies that @xmath117 .",
    "therefore , by induction , if there is a path of even length joining @xmath110 and @xmath111 we have that @xmath118 . according to the previous observations about graph @xmath51 this means that with overwhelming probability all words @xmath110 are equal . in particular , for any @xmath119 we have @xmath120 which implies that @xmath121 .",
    "therefore , all generators are equal .",
    "this ends the proof .",

    "in this chapter we are going to introduce van kampen diagrams , then prove the , , isoperimetric inequality  and discuss its consequences . as we will see",
    "it implies ( with overwhelming probability ) freeness of random groups for densities @xmath157 and hyperbolicity for @xmath158 .    the van kampen diagrams concept is a geometric way to represent how all equalities holding in a group are derived from combinations of relators .",
    "the definitions and notations below largely follow ( * ? ? ?",
    "[ def : van_kampen ] ( _ van kampen diagrams _ ) .",
    "let @xmath159 be a group presentation where all @xmath160 are cyclically reduced words in the free group @xmath161 .",
    "we will denote this presentation by @xmath162 .",
    "the alphabet @xmath46 and the set of defining relations @xmath95 are often assumed to be finite , which corresponds to a finite group presentation , but this assumption is not necessary for the general definition of a van kampen diagram .",
    "let @xmath163 be the symmetrized closure of @xmath95 , that is , let @xmath163 be obtained from @xmath95 by adding all cyclic permutations of elements of @xmath95 and of their inverses .",
    "a _ van kampen diagram _ over the presentation @xmath162 is a planar finite cell complex @xmath164 , given with a specific embedding @xmath165 with the following additional data and satisfying the following additional properties :    1 .",
    "the complex @xmath166 is connected and simply connected .",
    "each edge ( one - cell ) of @xmath166 is labelled by an arrow and a letter @xmath167 .",
    "some vertex ( zero - cell ) which belongs to the topological boundary of @xmath165 is specified as a base - vertex .",
    "4 .   for each region",
    "( two - cell ) of @xmath166 for every vertex the boundary cycle of that region and for each of the two choices of direction ( clockwise or counter - clockwise ) the label of the boundary cycle of the region read from that vertex and in that direction is a freely reduced word in @xmath161 that belongs to @xmath163 .",
    "a van kampen diagram @xmath166 is called _ non - reduced _ if there exists a _",
    "reduction pair _ in @xmath166 , that is , a pair of distinct regions of @xmath166 such that their boundary cycles share a common edge and such that their boundary cycles , read starting from that edge , clockwise for one of the regions and counter - clockwise for the other , are equal as words in @xmath168 . if no such pair of regions exists , @xmath166 is called _",
    "reduced_.    an _ internal edge _ is an edge @xmath37 such that @xmath169 .",
    "internal vertex _ is a vertex contained in @xmath170 .",
    "by @xmath171 we will denote the length of the boundary word of diagram @xmath172 and by @xmath173 the number of faces of @xmath172 .",
    "[ def : annular ] if in the definition above we replace simple connectivity by the assumption that our diagram is homotopically equivalent to an annulus , we get the definition of an _",
    "annular diagram_.    [ def : moebius ] if we change two things in definition [ def : van_kampen ] :    1 .",
    "replace the assumption that the cell complex is planar and given with a specific embedding into @xmath174 by the assumption that the cell complex is given with an embedding into the real projective plane 2 .",
    "replace simple connectivity by the assumption that our diagram is homotopically equivalent to the mbius strip .",
    "we get the definition of a _",
    "twisted diagram_.    an important theorem of van kampen states that the boundary words of van kampen diagrams are exactly those words which are equal to the identity element in the presentation .",
    "[ lem : parzy ] if in the presentation @xmath175 the set of relators @xmath95 consists of only positive words then for every van kampen diagram @xmath172 with respect to this presentation each internal vertex of @xmath172 has even valence .",
    "let @xmath87 be a vertex of @xmath172 and denote by @xmath176 consecutive edges of @xmath172 ending in @xmath87 .",
    "for @xmath177 let @xmath178 be the face containing edges @xmath179 and @xmath180 ( where @xmath181 ) .",
    "since the presentation consists of only positive words , for @xmath182 faces @xmath183 and @xmath184 have the opposite orientation and similarly @xmath185 and @xmath186 have the opposite orientation .",
    "therefore , the number of faces must be even , which implies that @xmath130 is an even number .    this lemma will be useful in the proof of theorem [ thm : once ] .",
    "now we are able to formulate and prove the following theorem ( inspired by ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 13 ) ) , which we will call `` isoperimetric inequality in the positive square model ''    [ thm : ie ] for any @xmath187 , in the positive square model at density @xmath188 with overwhelimg probability all reduced van kampen diagrams associated to the group presentation satisfy    @xmath189    note that our model can be considered as a special case of gromov s density model ( where @xmath9 = 4 ) .",
    "hence , proving theorem  [ thm : ie ] we will be mimicking the proof of the analogous theorem in gromov s model .",
    "there are only a few details that have to be changed .",
    "let us recall some definitions and propositions from `` proof of the density one half theorem '' in @xcite .",
    "an _ abstract diagram _ is a van kampen diagram in which we forget the actual relators associated with the faces , but only remember : the geometry of the diagram , which faces bear the same relator , the orientation , and the beginning points of relators .",
    "the @xmath190-tuple @xmath191 of cyclically reduced words is said to _ fulfill the abstract diagram _",
    "@xmath192 if there is a van kampen diagram formed by polygons bearing these words , which after forgetting the relators gives @xmath192",
    ". an abstract diagram is _ reduced _ if no edge is adjacent to two faces bearing the same relator with opposite orientations such that the edge is the @xmath130-th edge of both faces for some @xmath130 .",
    "see @xcite ( page 83 ) for details .",
    "the following proposition is inspired by ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition 58 )    [ prop : full ] let @xmath95 be a set of @xmath193 relators chosen randomly , with uniform distribution , from the set of positive words of length @xmath9 on @xmath0 generators .",
    "let @xmath192 be a reduced abstract diagram and let @xmath187 .",
    "then either @xmath194 or the probability that there exists a tuple of relators in @xmath95 fulfilling @xmath192 is less than @xmath195 .",
    "we will present the proof of this proposition in a more general form at the end of this chapter .",
    "now we will recall the theorem known as the  local - global principle  or the `` gromov  cartan  hadamard theorem '' .",
    "this principle has many different formulations .",
    "the variant best suited to our context is ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 60 ) which is a slight modification of ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition 8)    [ thm : lg ] let @xmath196 be a finite group presentation and let @xmath197 and @xmath198 be the minimal and maximal lengths of relator in @xmath95 . for a van kampen diagram @xmath192 with respect to the presentation set , we define :",
    "@xmath199 where @xmath200 is the length of the boundary path of face @xmath201 .",
    "let @xmath202 .",
    "choose @xmath187 .",
    "suppose that for some @xmath203 greater than @xmath204 any reduced van kampen diagram @xmath192 with @xmath205 satisfies    @xmath206 then any reduced van kampen diagram @xmath192 satisfies    @xmath207 and in particular the group is hyperbolic .",
    "now we are able to provide the proof of theorem [ thm : ie ] .",
    "our argumentation is very close to ollivier s .    in our case",
    "all relators in the presentation have the same length @xmath208 , so @xmath209 .",
    "in particular , the assumption @xmath210 in the theorem [ thm : lg ] becomes @xmath211 i.e. we have to check diagrams with at most @xmath203 faces .",
    "choose any @xmath187 .",
    "set @xmath212 and @xmath213 .",
    "let @xmath0 be the number of letters in the generating alphabet .",
    "let @xmath214 be the number of abstract reduced diagrams with at most @xmath203 square faces .",
    "we know from proposition  [ prop : full ] that for any fixed reduced abstract diagram @xmath192 violating the inequality @xmath215 the probability that it appears as a van kampen diagram of the presentation is @xmath216 . so the probability that there exists a reduced van kampen diagram with at most @xmath203 faces , violating the inequality is @xmath217 .",
    "observe that there are finitely many planar diagrams with at most @xmath203 square faces .",
    "there are also finitely many ways to decide which faces would bear the same relator , and also finitely many ways to choose the beginning point of each relator .",
    "therefore , the values @xmath218 have a uniform bound @xmath219 ( independent of @xmath0 ) .    hence , for fixed @xmath220 , @xmath221 . applying theorem [ thm : lg ] ( with our choice of @xmath222 and @xmath220 ) yields that all reduced van kampen diagrams @xmath192 satisfy @xmath223 as needed .",
    "[ cor : hyp ] in the positive square model at density @xmath188 a random group is hyperbolic with overwhelming probability .      in this section",
    "we consider a more general case where there are some fixed letters in the diagrams and the length of relators in the presentation equals @xmath9 .",
    "[ def : fix ] let @xmath46 be an abstract diagram .",
    "let @xmath224 be a set of @xmath203 distinct edges in @xmath46 .",
    "we call them _ fixed edges ( of a)_. let @xmath225 be a sequence of generators labeling edges @xmath224 successively and according to the orientation of the face or faces containing @xmath226 .",
    "we call these generators _ fixed letters ( of a)_. we call such a diagram with some labellings on edges an _ abstract diagram with @xmath203 fixed edges_.    we say that a tuple of relators _ fulfills _ @xmath46 if this tuple fulfills @xmath46 as an abstract diagram and this fulfilling is consistent with labels on fixed edges .",
    "our goal is to prove the following statement    [ thm : lab ] let r be a set of @xmath193 relators chosen randomly , with uniform distribution , from the set of positive words of length @xmath9 on @xmath0 generators .",
    "let @xmath46 be an abstract diagram with @xmath203 fixed edges and let @xmath187 . then either @xmath227 or the probability that there exists a tuple of relators in @xmath95 fulfilling @xmath46 is @xmath228 .",
    "our proof is based on the proof of ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition 58 ) . to prove our theorem we need some more definitions .",
    "let @xmath229 be the number of distinct relators in @xmath46 .",
    "for @xmath230 let @xmath231 be the number of faces bearing relator @xmath232 .",
    "up to reordering the relators we can suppose that @xmath233 .    for @xmath234 and @xmath235",
    "we say that @xmath236 if @xmath237 or @xmath238 but @xmath239 .",
    "let @xmath37 be an edge of @xmath46 adjacent to faces @xmath240 bearing relators @xmath241 and @xmath242 , which is the @xmath243-th edge of @xmath244 and @xmath245-th edge of @xmath246 .",
    "if @xmath37 is not a fixed edge we say that @xmath37 _ belongs _ to @xmath244 if @xmath236 and @xmath37 _ belongs _ to @xmath246 if @xmath247 .",
    "if @xmath37 is a fixed edge then we say that @xmath37 _ belongs _ to both faces : @xmath244 and @xmath246 .",
    "if @xmath248 is a fixed edge which is adjacent to face @xmath201 and @xmath248 is a boundary edge , then we say that @xmath248 _ belongs _ to @xmath201 .",
    "note that since @xmath46 is reduced , then each internal edge , which is not a fixed edge , belongs to some face : indeed if @xmath249 then either the two faces have opposite orientations and then @xmath46 is not reduced , or they have the same orientations and the diagram is never fulfillable since a letter would be its own inverse .",
    "let @xmath250 be the number of edges belonging to face @xmath201 .",
    "since each internal edge which is not a fixed edge belongs to some face we have :    @xmath251    for @xmath230 let    @xmath252    then : @xmath253 for @xmath230 let @xmath254 be the probability that @xmath232 randomly chosen positive words @xmath255 partially fulfill @xmath46 and let @xmath256 .",
    "then @xmath257    suppose that first @xmath258 words @xmath259 partially fulfilling @xmath46 are given .",
    "then successively choose the letters of the word @xmath260 in a way to fulfill the diagram .",
    "let @xmath261 and suppose that the first @xmath262 letters of @xmath260 are chosen .",
    "let @xmath201 be the face realizing the maximum of @xmath263 and let @xmath37 be the @xmath130-th edge of the face @xmath201 .",
    "if @xmath37 belongs to @xmath201 this means that there is another face @xmath264 meeting @xmath37 which bears relator @xmath265 or bears @xmath232 too , but @xmath266 appears in @xmath264 as a @xmath267-th edge for @xmath268 or @xmath37 is a fixed edge . in all these cases the letter on the edge @xmath37",
    "is imposed by some letter already chosen so drawing it at random has probability @xmath269 .    combining all these observations we get that the probability to choose at random the correct word @xmath260 is at most @xmath270 .",
    "now we can provide the proof of theorem [ thm : lab ] .    for @xmath271 let @xmath272 be the probability that there exists a @xmath232-tuple of words partially fulfilling @xmath46 in the random set of relators @xmath95 .",
    "we trivially have :    @xmath273    combining equations ( [ eq:2 ] ) and ( [ eq:3 ] ) we get    @xmath274 @xmath275    now @xmath256 so @xmath276 and we have    @xmath277    now using ( [ eq:4 ] ) and again the fact that @xmath278 we have    @xmath279    observe that @xmath280 . hence    @xmath281    setting @xmath282 and using that @xmath283 we get    @xmath284 @xmath285 since @xmath286",
    "of course a diagram is fulfillable if it is partially fulfillable for any @xmath287 and so    @xmath288 which was to be proven .",
    "proposition [ prop : full ] results as a special case of theorem [ thm : lab ] when there are no fixed letters .      in this section",
    "we are going to prove that all previous results remain true in the square model .",

    ".    now we are able to prove the isoperimetric inequality for the square model :    [ thm : ies ] for any @xmath187 , in the square model at density @xmath188 with overwhelimg probability all reduced van kampen diagrams associated to the group presentation satisfy :    @xmath189    the proof is completely analogous to the proof of theorem [ thm : ie ] : the only change is that we have to use the theorem [ thm : labs ] , instead of proposition [ prop : full ] , to obtain that for any fixed reduced abstract diagram @xmath192 violating the inequality @xmath215 the probability that it appears as a van kampen diagram of the presentation is @xmath296 , which is @xmath297 .",
    "[ cor : hyps ] in the square model at density @xmath188 a random group is hyperbolic with overwhelming probability .",
    "in this chapter we are going to consider the case where density of relations is small .",
    "our goal is to prove the following statement :    [ thm : free ] in the positive square model at density @xmath298 a random group is free with overwhelming probability .    to provide the proof of this theorem we will introduce several geometric objects :    [ def : complex ] a",
    "_ square complex _ is a metric polyhedral complex in which each cell is isometric to the euclidean square @xmath299 ^ 2 $ ] and the gluing maps are isometries .",
    "observe that we allow to glue a cell to itself and to glue two cells several times along distinct pairs of faces .",
    "notice that van kampen diagrams in the positive square model are square complexes .",
    "now we will introduce one of the basic notions in geometric group theory : hypergraphs .",
    "the following definitions are taken from ( * ? ? ?",
    "* definition 2.1 ) .",
    "[ def : hyp ] let @xmath300 be a connected square complex .",
    "we define a graph @xmath301 as follows : the set of vertices of @xmath301 is the set of @xmath10-cells of @xmath300 .",
    "there is an edge in @xmath301 between two vertices if there is some @xmath302-cell @xmath95 of @xmath300 such that these vertices correspond to opposite @xmath10-cells in the boundary of @xmath95 ( if there are several such @xmath302-cells we put as many edges in @xmath301 ) .",
    "the @xmath302-cell @xmath95 is the @xmath302-cell of @xmath300 _ containing _ the edge .",
    "there is a natural map @xmath303 from @xmath301 to @xmath300 , which sends each vertex of @xmath301 to the midpoint of the corresponding @xmath10-cell of @xmath300 and each edge of @xmath301 to a segment joining two opposite points in the @xmath302-cell @xmath95 .",
    "note that the images of two edges contained in the same @xmath302-cell @xmath95 always intersect , so that in general @xmath303 is not an embedding .",
    "a _ hypergraph _ in @xmath300 is a connected component of @xmath301 .",
    "the @xmath10-cells of @xmath300 through which a hypergraph passes are _ dual _ to it .",
    "the hypergraph @xmath304 _ embeds _ if @xmath303 is an embedding from @xmath304 to @xmath300 , that is , if no two distinct edges of @xmath304 are mapped to the same @xmath302-cell of @xmath300 .",
    "we call the subdiagram of @xmath300 consisting of all open faces containing edges of the hypergraph @xmath304 the _ carrier of _ @xmath304 .",
    "the next definition we will give is one of the typical ways to construct a topological space @xmath300 such that @xmath305 for given a finitely generated group @xmath51 , .",
    "[ def : pres_complex ] let @xmath306 be a group generated by @xmath0 elements . consider a bouquet of @xmath0 circles labeled with elements of @xmath21 .",
    "for every relator @xmath160 there is a polygon with as many edges as letters in @xmath307 , which is glued to the bouquet in the following way : the edge labeled by @xmath308 is glued to the circle with label @xmath309 respecting the orientation . for a random group in the square or positive square model",
    "this construction results in a square complex , which we call the _ presentation complex_.    there is a natural map from any van kampen diagram to the presentation complex of @xmath51 .",
    "one of the main steps in our proof of theorem [ thm : free ] is the following statement :    [ thm : ftree ] in the positive square model at density @xmath298 with overwhelming probability all hypergraphs in the presentation complex are embedded trees .",
    "denote the presentation complex of a random group by @xmath300 .",
    "we will estimate the probability @xmath29 of drawing the set of relators @xmath28 for which the statement does not hold , i.e. there exists a hypergraph in @xmath300 which is not an embedded tree .    hence , let us assume that such a hypergraph exists and call it @xmath304 .",
    "the image of @xmath304 under the natural map is not a tree , so @xmath304 contains a _ circuit _ ( an edge path @xmath310 in @xmath304 such that images of @xmath311 and @xmath312 intersect in @xmath300 ) . without loss of generality we can assume that @xmath130 is the minimal possible length of a circuit . for @xmath313 , let @xmath183 be the @xmath302-cell of @xmath300 containing the edge @xmath179 .",
    "we have chosen the circuit of the minimal length , so @xmath314 and @xmath315 for @xmath316 , except where @xmath317 .",
    "let @xmath192 be a diagram consisting of faces @xmath318 glued in the following way : for @xmath182 faces @xmath183 and @xmath184 are glued along @xmath10-cells which contain the common vertex of @xmath179 and @xmath180 .",
    "it can be easily seen that @xmath192 is either : an annular diagram , a twisted diagram or a van kampen diagram .",
    "we will estimate a probability @xmath99 of drawing the set of relators which allows to construct a diagram with @xmath130 faces and exactly @xmath319 edges and consisting of distinct relators ( @xmath192 has these properties ) .",
    "let @xmath320 be the abstract diagram obtained from @xmath192 .",
    "there are @xmath321 @xmath322tuples of relators fulfilling @xmath320 .",
    "denote by @xmath323 the set of these @xmath322tuples . to fulfill @xmath320 one of the elements @xmath324 must be a subset of the set of drawn words @xmath28 .    for @xmath324 let @xmath325 be the probability of drawing the set @xmath28 which contains @xmath326 .",
    "then :    @xmath327 hence :    @xmath328    we have @xmath329 . to estimate the probability of the existence of a hypergraph , that is not an embedded tree , we sum @xmath99 over all possible @xmath130 :    @xmath330    we assumed that @xmath298 , so the right hand side of ( [ eq : free ] ) converges to 0 when @xmath17 .",
    "let us recall one of the applications of the hnn extension construction :    [ thm : hnn ] let @xmath54 be a hausdorff topological space and let @xmath331 be two distinct , simply - connected and path - connected subsets such that there is a homeomorphism @xmath332 . by @xmath333 we denote the topological space @xmath334 , where the relation @xmath335 is defined as follows : @xmath336 for all @xmath337 .",
    ".    now we are ready to provide the proof of the freeness theorem .    from theorem [ thm : ftree ]",
    "we know that with overwhelming probability all hypergraphs in the presentation complex @xmath300 are embedded trees .",
    "let us take an arbitrary hypergraph @xmath304 .",
    "let @xmath339 be the carrier of @xmath304 .",
    "let us consider the complex @xmath340 ( by @xmath341 we denote the completion of the complex @xmath46 in the path metric ) .",
    "note that @xmath342 consists of two isometric copies of @xmath304 denoted : @xmath343 and @xmath344 .",
    "let @xmath345 be the homeomorphism between @xmath343 and @xmath344 .",
    "@xmath346 is homotopically equivalent to @xmath340 and @xmath347 .",
    "moreover the space @xmath348 is equal to the complex @xmath300 .",
    "hence @xmath349 , and by theorem [ thm : hnn ] we obtain @xmath350 .",
    "we now perform the same procedure for the subcomplex @xmath351 .",
    "we choose an arbitrary hypergraph in @xmath352 and remove its carrier from @xmath352 obtaining a smaller complex @xmath353 . by theorem [ thm :",
    "hnn ] : @xmath354 .",
    "we now inductively repeat this procedure .",
    "note that the presentation complex is finite and each time we remove at least one cell , so this induction must stop after a finite number @xmath7 of steps .",
    "let @xmath355 be the subcomplex obtained after @xmath7 steps .",
    "we can not perform this procedure on @xmath355 which specifically means that there are no hypergraphs in @xmath355 .",
    "but the only square complex with no hypergraphs is the square complex consisting of one vertex , which has the trivial fundamental group .",
    "therefore @xmath356 .",
    "hence @xmath357 is a free group with overwhelming probability .",
    "first , we will prove the following    [ thm : ftrees ] in the square model at density @xmath298 with overwhelming probability all hypergraphs in the presentation complex are embedded trees .",
    "as in the proof of theorem [ thm : ftree ] we only need to prove that with overwhelming probability there are no diagrams with @xmath130 faces and exactly @xmath319 edges in the presentation complex for any @xmath130 .",
    "let @xmath320 be such an abstract diagram with the minimal number of faces .",
    "we will estimate the probability @xmath99 of drawing the set of relators such that @xmath320 can be fulfilled .",
    "there are at most @xmath358 @xmath322tuples of relators fulfilling @xmath320 .",

    "denote by @xmath323 the set of these @xmath322tuples . to fulfill @xmath320 one of the @xmath130-tuples",
    "@xmath324 must be a subset of the set of drawn words @xmath28 .    for @xmath324 let @xmath325 be the probability of drawing the set @xmath28 which contains @xmath326",
    ". then    @xmath361 hence    @xmath362    note that @xmath363 which , for any @xmath364 is greater than @xmath365 for a sufficiently large @xmath0 .",
    "therefore , we can estimate the right hand side of ( [ eq : pozs ] ) by @xmath366 . as in the proof of theorem [ thm : ftree ] we estimate the sum of @xmath99 over all possible @xmath130    @xmath367    we assumed that @xmath298 , so we can choose @xmath368 and @xmath364 , such that @xmath369 .",
    "then the right hand side of ( [ eq : frees ] ) converges to 0 when @xmath17 .",
    "[ thm : frees ] in the square model at density @xmath298 a random group is free with overwhelming probability .    the proof is identical to the proof of theorem [ thm : free ] with the only one change : we use now theorem [ thm : ftrees ] instead of theorem [ thm : ftree ] .",
    "in this chapter our goal is to prove the following statement      first , we will define _ kazhdan s property _ ( t ) and formulate some basic facts .",
    "here we are only concerned with discrete , finitely generated groups . for a more complete treatment including property ( t ) see @xcite .",
    "let @xmath301 be a finitely generated group with a finite generating set @xmath58 .",
    "let @xmath339 be a hilbert space and @xmath371 a unitary representation of @xmath301 on @xmath339 .",
    "we will say that @xmath372 has _ almost invariant vectors _ if for every @xmath187 there exists @xmath373 such that for every @xmath374 we have @xmath375 .",

    ".          we will be mimicking the proof of the analogous theorem in gromov s model which states that for densities @xmath379 a random group in the gromov density model does not have property ( t ) with overwhelming probability @xcite .",
    "we say that a reduced van kampen diagram @xmath192 is a _ collared diagram _ if there is a vertex @xmath87 in the boundary such that for every other boundary vertex there is exactly one internal edge which ends in this vertex .",
    "moreover , we assume that @xmath87 is the end of exactly @xmath140 , @xmath10 or maximally @xmath302 internal edges .          moreover , there is a natural combinatorial map @xmath383 such that the image @xmath384 is a hypergraf segment in @xmath380 . for such @xmath382",
    "we say that @xmath192 is _ collared _ by segment @xmath384 .",
    "the definition is illustrated in figure [ fig : col ] .      in (",
    "* definition 3.11 ) ollivier and wise defined diagrams collared by hypergraphs and paths for an arbitrary length @xmath9 of relators .",
    "their definition coincides with ours for @xmath208 , the number of collaring hypergraphs equal 1 and the number of collaring paths equal 0 .",
    "the following theorem shows the relation between collared diagrams and hypergraphs :        assume on the contrary that there is a hypergraph which is not an embedded tree . from theorem [ thm : collar ]",
    "we know that there is a diagram @xmath192 collared by some segment @xmath382 .",
    "let @xmath385 . for @xmath386 from theorem",

    "[ thm : cp ] let @xmath304 be a hypergraph that is an embedded tree in @xmath380 .",

    "[ thm : ie ] ( isoperimetric inequality ) we have that with overwhelming probability :                  since hypergraphs are trees in @xmath380 , their stabilizers act freely on a tree .",
    "groups acting freely on trees are free ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 4 ) .",
    "moreover , random groups for densities @xmath12 are hyperbolic .",
    "now a quasi - isometrically embedded space in a hyperbolic space is quasiconvex .",
    "let @xmath192 be a reduced van kampen diagram @xmath192 and let @xmath399 be all the vertices on its boundary in that order .",
    "suppose that for some @xmath400 the following holds : for every @xmath435 there is exactly one internal edge @xmath312 ending in @xmath402 .",
    "moreover , we assume that for @xmath436 there are exactly 0 or 2 internal edges ending in @xmath87 .",
    "it can be easily seen that there are two hypergraph segments @xmath437 , @xmath438 in @xmath192 such that for @xmath439 edges @xmath312 are dual to @xmath437 and for @xmath440 edges @xmath312 are dual to @xmath438 and internal edges ending in @xmath403 and @xmath404 are dual to both segments .",
    "there are exactly two cells containing edges of both segments @xmath437 , @xmath438 , called _",
    "corners_. there is a natural combinatorial map @xmath383 such that @xmath441 and @xmath442 are hypergraph segments in @xmath380 . in such a case we say that @xmath192 is _ collared by segments @xmath441 and @xmath442_.        our definition coincides with the one given by ollivier and wise in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* definition 3.11 ) for the length of relators equal 4 , the number of collaring segments equal 2 and the number of collaring paths equal 0 .",
    "[ thm : segments ] let @xmath343 and @xmath344 be two distinct hypergraphs in @xmath380 that are embedded trees .",
    "there is more than one point in @xmath443 if and only if there exists a reduced diagram @xmath320 collared by segments of @xmath343 and @xmath344 .",
    "moreover , if @xmath343 and @xmath344 cross at a 2-cell @xmath222 we can choose @xmath320 so that @xmath222 is one of these corners .",
    "let us consider a pair of hypergraphs @xmath304 , @xmath444 intersecting at least two times .",
    "assume that @xmath304 and @xmath444 cross at a 2-cell @xmath222 . from theorem [ thm : segments ]",
    "we know that there exists a diagram @xmath320 collared by segments @xmath445 and @xmath446 such that @xmath222 is its corner .",
    "note that @xmath447 and @xmath448 . from theorem [ thm : ie ] ( isoperimetric inequality )",
    "we obtain that with overwhelming probability :    @xmath449 , which implies @xmath450 .",
    "moreover @xmath451 .",
    "therefore , all possibilities which do not violate ( [ eq : trzy ] ) are : @xmath452 , @xmath453 and @xmath454 .",
    "there are only three 2-collared diagrams satisfying ( [ eq : trzy ] ) ( see figure [ fig : diagi ] )          for each 2-cell @xmath457 consider two hypergraphs passing through @xmath458 .",
    "assume , contrary to our conclusion , that each such pair of hypergraphs has at least two points in the intersection . according to our previous discussion this means that for each relator @xmath307 in the presentation there is a van kampen diagram @xmath320 of form @xmath309 or @xmath456 ( see figure [ fig : diagi ] ) such that its corner bears @xmath307 .",
    "we can draw relators in two steps : in the first step we draw one relator @xmath307 and in the second step we draw @xmath459 remaining relators from the set @xmath460 .",
    "this way of drawing the presentation gives us a specific relator @xmath307 .",
    "we will show that with overwhelming probability relator @xmath307 is not borne by a corner in any van kampen diagram of the shape @xmath309 or @xmath456 .",
    "the probability that there exists a van kampen diagram of type @xmath309 or @xmath456 such that its corner bears @xmath307 is the same as the probability that one of the abstract diagrams presented in figure [ fig : dlab ] ( where @xmath83 are two consecutive edges of @xmath307 ) can be fulfilled by the tuple from the random set of relators .",
    "to fulfill @xmath320 we can use @xmath307 and other relators .",
    "observe that since with overwhelming probability @xmath307 consists of different letters and @xmath307 is a positive word , than two faces bearing relator @xmath307 can not be adjacent ( such a pair of faces would make a reduction pair ) .    hence , diagram @xmath462 can be fulfilled only by a relator different than @xmath307 .",
    "let @xmath463 be the probability of fulfilling @xmath462 .",
    "observe that @xmath462 is an abstract diagram with two fixed letters and one face .",
    "moreover , note that @xmath464 so from theorem [ thm : lab ] ( used for @xmath208 ) the probability of fulfilling @xmath462 is less than @xmath465 for any @xmath466 .",
    "let us fix some @xmath466 .    according to the previous observation about faces bearing @xmath307",
    ", there can be maximally two faces bearing @xmath307 in @xmath456 in order to fulfill the diagram .",
    "hence , there can be maximally one face bearing @xmath307 in @xmath467 .",
    "let @xmath468 be the probability of fulfilling @xmath467 without using the relator @xmath307 .",
    "the diagram @xmath467 is an abstract diagram with two fixed letters and satisfies @xmath469 , so again using theorem [ thm : lab ] we obtain that @xmath470 .",
    "now we will estimate the probability @xmath471 of fulfilling @xmath456 using the relator @xmath307 two times .",
    "the only face in @xmath467 which can bear @xmath307 is the right bottom face .",
    "we can , therefore , consider diagram @xmath472 where we remove this face and label the new boundary edges with three consecutive letters of @xmath307 ( see figure [ fig:2bis ] ) .        for a fixed relator @xmath307",

    "therefore , from the bayes formula we can estimate the probability of fulfilling @xmath320 by :      therefore , choosing a @xmath302-cell in @xmath380 bearing the first relator and taking 2 hypergraphs passing through this cell , with overwhelming probability , gives us a pair of hypergraphs which cross only once .",
    "note , that a hypergraph can have a leaf only if there exists a generator which appears in exacly one relator .",
    "let us consider a fixed generator @xmath309 .",
    "the number of positive words of length 4 containing generator @xmath309 equals @xmath482 , so @xmath483 is the number of presentations where exactly one relator contains @xmath309 .",
    "hence the probability that @xmath309 appears in exactly one relator equals :              the probability that there exists a generator that is contained in exactly one relator is bounded by @xmath489 .",
    "let us denote @xmath490 .",
    "note that @xmath491 , so it suffices to show that @xmath69 .",
    "note that : @xmath492 .",
    "from the fact that @xmath70 for @xmath71 , we can estimate :        [ [ for - densities - frac14-d - frac13-a - random - group - in - the - positive - square - model - does - not - have - property - t ] ] for densities @xmath3 a random group in the positive square model does not have property ( t ) ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~        [ thm : numb ] suppose that a group @xmath51 acts cocompactly and freely on @xmath380 and the system of hypergraphs in @xmath380 is locally finite and cocompact ( meaning that the hypergrahs in @xmath498 are compact and there is a finite number of them ) .",
    "suppose that two distinct leafless hypergraphs @xmath343 and @xmath344 , which are embedded trees , cross at a single point .",
    "[ thm : faj ] in the positive square model at density @xmath3 with overwhelming probability a random group @xmath51 has a subgroup @xmath339 which is free , quasiconvex and such that the relative number of ends @xmath502 is at least 2 .",
    "in particular with overwhelming probability @xmath51 does not have property _",
    "( t)_.    from lemma [ lem : et ] we know that with overwhelming probability hypergraphs in @xmath380 are embedded trees . then from corollary [ cor : sub ] we know that with overwhelming probability @xmath497 of any hypergraph @xmath304 is a free , quasiconvex subgroup , hence so is @xmath495 since it is a subgroup in @xmath497 of index @xmath496 .    the presentation complex @xmath300 of @xmath51 is finite since our group is finitely presented so @xmath51 acts cocompactly on @xmath380 and the system of hypergraphs is locally finite and cocompact . from theorem [ thm : once ] we know that with overwhelming probability there is a pair of hypergraphs which intersect exactly once and from lemma [ lem : leaf ] we have that with overwhelming probability all hypergraphs are leafless trees ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we introduce a new random group model called the _ square model _ : we quotient a free group on @xmath0 generators by a random set of relations , each of which is a reduced word of length four . </S>",
    "<S> we prove , as in the gromov model introduced in @xcite , that for densities @xmath1 a random group in the square model is trivial with overwhelming probability and for densities @xmath2 a random group is with overwhelming probability hyperbolic . </S>",
    "<S> moreover we show that for densities @xmath3 a random group in the square model does not have property ( t ) . </S>",
    "<S> inspired by the results for the triangular model we prove that for densities @xmath4 in the square model , a random group is free with overwhelming probability . </S>",
    "<S> we also introduce abstract diagrams with fixed edges and prove a generalization of the isoperimetric inequality . </S>"
  ]
}
